newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul shrs end at 3-yr low on supply, probe fears.
newsitem.headline: Seoul shrs end at 3-yr low on supply, probe fears.

text.p: Stocks tumbled throughout Tuesday's trading as investors hurriedly dumped shares on fears that a huge oversupply of new stocks this month would spell disaster for the rudderless market, brokers said.
The uncertain atmosphere was further dampened by the government's on-going anti-corruption campaign, which could further destabilise stock prices, they added.
The composite stock index fell 13.74 points, or 1.84 percent, to a provisional close of 733.68.
This was the lowest close since October 12, 1993, when the market closed at 723.57.
Brokers and analysts said the market's collapse over the past two days were linked more to a shift in sentiment than a sudden change in fundamentals.

"Everyone knew about the margin loans and the oversupply of shares. It's now a psychological issue. People are really afraid to hold shares," said Choi Tae-hwan, head of sales department at KLB Securities.
"The 750 line was seen as a strong support," market analyst Steven Lee of Shinyoung Securities earlier said.
"Once that line was broken (on Monday), people didn't know where it would stop," Lee said.

Loans for margin trading are at a record high of around three trillion won, while customer deposits have declined to around 2.5 trillion. Between 500-900 billion won worth of the loans will have to be repaid this month, brokers said.
New stock supply in November is estimated at more than 1.1 trillion won, they added.
The exchange later revised the index to 733.65, down 13.77 points or 1.84 percent on the day.
Brokers said investors were worried that the corruption investigations would also look into illicit share trading and could cause big investors to pull money out of the market.
President Kim Young-sam has staked his political reputation on fighting corruption, but was recently embarrassed by the arrest of a former defence minister for accepting bribes.
Prosecution officials have said the current drive would cover all levels of civil servants and would last till 1998.
Small-cap and second-tier shares, which had led the market's gains this year, bore the brunt of the selling.
Tae Heung Leather fell 500 won to 12,400. Sammi Steel lost 70 won to 4,160. Tongil Heavy Industry shed 140 won to 4,660.
Heavily weighted blue chips saw some buying late on bargain hunting. Samsung Electronics rose 1,500 won to 60,700. Korea Mobile Telecom gained 16,000 won to 450,000.
The December futures ended down 0.10 of a point to 78.50, while the KOSPI 200 index lost 1.02 points to 76.93.
